ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I gained a comprehensive knowledge of the history of Puerto Rico and valuable skills in primary source research.
I gained invaluable insight into the history of Puerto Ricos relationship with the US and the memorable events that shaped it.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I believe the course discussion could be made more lively if guided by the Professor in a more Socratic fashion, although it is very informative in the structure it has currently. Overall, the course covers a lot of ground and is very profound. Strongly recommend.
The professor still often ran the course as a lecture, even though there were only 9 students in the class. I would have appreciated more time to discuss the readings in seminar style.
The greatest strenght is its professor! Collado-Schwartz is spectacular and provides great discussions.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Definitely. The course explores a topic rarely taught at American universities and does a great job at exploring the political uniqueness of Puerto Rico from the point of view of an insider. Prof. Collado Schwarz is a font of knowledge.
Yes. The history of Puerto Rico is a very tricky subject to teach but the professor did a great job!
